explanation: The original code only checked whether the exact string S was already in the set Z. It relied on having previously added both a string and its reverse into Z to detect reversed duplicates. To be robust and explicit (and to ensure reversed occurrences are recognized even if only one direction was recorded), the check should test for either S or its reverse being in Z. I fixed the single line by changing the if-condition to check both S in Z or S[::-1] in Z.
fixed_code:
N = int(input())

Z = set()

count = 0
for i in range(N):
    S = input()
    if S in Z or S[::-1] in Z:
        count += 1
    Z.add(S)
    Z.add(S[::-1])

print(count)
